summary:
His brother was carrying a child, and neither he nor Wei Wuxian seemed surprised that he was there. Lan Xichen felt mounting dread build up inside him.

“Xichen-ge!” Wei Wuxian called out, waving cheerfully. “Xichen-ge, guess what? We’re parents now!”

(Wherein a time-traveling Wangxian have absolutely no self-control, and everyone else is just slowly losing their minds).

Here's another fic in this series! text:
A Visit to Lotus Pier 

It happened a few days after their return from their honeymoon (a full week of sight-seeing, sex, and putting their future plans into place). Wei Wuxian had spent the last few days in a state of bliss and excitement. He had travelled to the past, and he had a chance to put a stop to the horrors of the future — and, if that wasn’t enough of a blessing, he had Lan Wangji, his Lan Zhan, by his side. 
Lan Zhan loved him. Lan Zhan was his husband. 
The excitement of the last few days seemed to have kept the nightmares at bay, but after the pain he had experienced in his own timeline, Wei Wuxian was hardly going to just forget about all of it. He woke up suddenly that night, thrashing in the sheets, crying out for his sister.
“Wei Ying!” Lan Wangji cried, his eyes wide in concern.
“Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian sobbed, curled in his husband’s embrace. “Lan Zhan…I need to go to Lotus Pier.”
It was the middle of the night, and perhaps it would be best to wait until the morning, and tell everyone where they were going. They were technically students at the moment, and they hadn’t done a very good job at hiding who they were to begin with.
And yet, all Wei Wuxian could think was, ‘Shijie is alive. Shijie is ALIVE,’ and there was no way he could go back to sleep and pretend that this revelation hadn’t finally hit him at full force. He needed to see his sister. 
Lan Wangji didn’t try to dissuade him, or tell him to wait. Instead, his wonderful husband helped him dress, and the two of them quickly mounted their swords (Wei Wuxian marvelling the feel of being on Suibian again at last), and headed off towards Lotus Pier.
(The next morning, their exhausted relatives would wonder where they had vanished again).
…
Jiang Fengmian had been fully intending to tell his wife about Wei Wuxian’s sudden marriage. The problem was, he just couldn’t work out how to say it. The whole situation was just so bizarre, and he wasn’t sure how to explain that their adopted son had run off with a boy he had only just met, and gotten married to him.
Yu Ziyuan would undoubtedly lose her mind, and Jiang Fengmian, exhausted after a long day having to deal with a furious Lan Qiren, and whatever the hell was going on with Wei Wuxian, had resolutely decided that he just didn’t want to deal with it. 
He would wait until he had processed the whole situation, and then he would tell her. 
Of course, he didn’t foresee Wei Wuxian suddenly bursting into the dining room a few days later, dragging his new husband behind him. The Jiangs, who had just started their breakfast, all turned to stare at him.
“Shijie!” Wei Wuxian cried, throwing himself forward. “Shijie, I missed you so much!”
“A-Xian!” Jiang Yanli jumped to her feet, and rushed forward. She had never been able to say no to her little brothers, and she immediately gathered him into her arms, holding him close.
Madam Yu was finally able to shake off her shock, and jumped to her feet, her expression quickly turning to one of rage. “Just what is going on here?!” 
“Oh A-Xian, what’s wrong?” Jiang Yanli asked, her eyes wide in concern. “Are you alright? Are you hurt?” 
“A-Li!” Madam Yu snapped. “Remember your place. Wei Wuxian — I have no idea what you think you’re doing here — ”
“I just missed you!” Wei Wuxian sobbed, burying himself closer. 
“You’ve been gone for a week, A-Xian,” Jiang Yanli said, with amusement in her voice. Though she knew she should probably do something to ease her mother’s anger, her little brothers always came first. “XianXian can’t go a week without his big sister?” 
“No, XianXian can’t,” Wei Wuxian said, shaking his head. “Shijie, I have so much to tell you. I got married, you know?!” 
Jiang Yanli, of course, thought that this was a joke. While Jiang Cheng had told her all about Wei Wuxian's 'horrific' confession, and how he and the Second Jade of Lan had disappeared together, he hadn't actually gotten around to telling his sister about the whole marriage part of it.
Madam Yu, who scoffed in disgust, thought that this was a joke.
Jiang Fengmian grimaced and looked away, preparing himself for the inevitable fallout. 
“Has A-Xian been flirting with all of the girls in Gusu?” Jiang Yanli asked, smiling teasingly. 
Lan Wangji’s expression darkened. Wei Wuxian glanced at him, and then shook his head hurriedly. “Oh no, Shijie! No girls, just my Lan Zhan! He’s all I need!” And then he pulled himself out of his sister’s hug, and walked over to Lan Wangji. “Lan Zhan,” he said, “there’s no reason to look like that! You’re the love of my life, the only person, man or women, I’ll ever need that way!” 
“Mn,” Lan Wangji said, ducking his head slightly.
“No really!” Wei Wuxian said insistently. “I love you, remember? I fancy you, I whatever you — ”
Lan Wangji tugged him close, and murmured, his voice low, “Mark your words.”
Wei Wuxian shuddered, suddenly feeling warm all over. The room seemed to melt away, and he momentarily forgot that he was surrounded by his family.
“A-Xian,” Jiang Fengmian said, trying to keep his voice even, and hide the discomfort that he was feeling. “I…really don’t think that this is the place.”
Madam Yu turned to him, her expression dangerous. Jiang Yanli continued to watch on, her eyes wide as she realised that this wasn’t a joke after all.
“What,” she hissed, “is this?” 
Jiang Fengmian shifted uncomfortably. “My Lady,” he said, “I…well, I had fully intended to tell you about all of this — ”
“And what exactly is this?” 
“…It appears that A-Xian and the Second Master Lan have…married each other?”
Silence.
“Oh, and don’t feel offended,” Wei Wuxian added quickly. “It was really small — just the two of us, really. We didn’t want a huge thing — ”

“Excuse me?!”

“And actually, it was a good way to save money, because who needs to waste so much on a huge wedding? All Lan Zhan and I really needed was each other!” 
“Explain to me,” Madam Yu said, her voice thunderous, “just how you left for Gusu a little over a week ago, and you are somehow already married.”
“Huh?” Wei Wuxian’s brow furrowed slightly. “Oh no, we got married after the first day, we just took a week to - ”
“I think what A-Xian means,” Jiang Fengmian said loudly, “is that — well — ” And oh, Jiang Fengmian was honestly trying his best to diffuse the situation. He seemed to have forgotten that the very sound of his voice only served to make his wife angrier, and that there was really no way to make this seem less bizarre than it really was. 
“Are you actually defending this behaviour?!” Madam Yu snapped. “He is our Head Disciple, and yet he acts to foolishly and rashly?! How does this look for our Sect? And what do Gusu Lan think they are doing, not even bothering to tell us — ?” 
Jiang Fengmian winced and looked away. 
“Sect Leader Jiang is aware of our marriage,” Lan Wangji said. He had chosen to remain silent up until now, happy to let the adults carry out their argument while he quietly admired the beauty of his husband. Wei Wuxian simply looked radiant in his joy at seeing his family alive again.

“WHAT?!” 

“Mother, Father,” Jiang Yanli said, smiling gently. “Perhaps I should take A-Xian and Young Master Lan outside while you two continue this discussion?”
“Absolutely not — ” Madam Yu started to say, and then remembered that they currently had a guest from a very prominent sect. As furious as she was with the Lans at the moment, she was hardly going to embarrass her own sect in front of them.
“Fine,” she said at last. “Take them out from my sight, right now, while your father explains exactly why he didn’t tell me about this before.”
“By Madam Yu, by Uncle Jiang!” Wei Wuxian said, waving cheerfully. “I missed you!”
“Get the hell out!”
When they were a far distance away from the dining room, Jiang Yanli turned to face the newlyweds. For a moment she simply watched them, and then turned to meet her brother’s gaze, a small smile on her lips.
“A-Xian, you look happy,” she said. 
“I’m very happy,” Wei Wuxian agreed. “I have Lan Zhan, and Shijie, and our family — how could I not be?” 
Jiang Yanli laughed, shaking her head slightly. “You never knew how to do things half way, did you?” She then turned to Lan Wangji, and the gentle expression morphed into something else. Wei Wuxian continued to bask in the joy of being with his two favourite people, but Lan Wangji, who was a master of minute changes to one’s expression, could see the dangerous glint in her eyes. 
“Young Master Lan,” Jiang Yanli said, “I think the two of us need to have a long chat.”
Lan Wangji nodded. “Of course.” 
...
 Qingheng-Jun’s Nightmare  
A short while after Wei Wuxian had moved to the Cloud Recesses permanently (much to the horror of Lan Qiren) a meeting was held, with Lan Qiren, Lan Xichen, and the Lan Elders in attendance. 
“Something needs to be done,” one of the elders said, his expression dark. “This cannot go on much longer.”
There were nods and murmurs of agreement around the room.
“Perhaps someone can…talk to them?” Everyone exchanged wary glances, and no one volunteered to do so.
“Perhaps Lan Xichen should,” another elder suggested. “After all, Lan Wangji is his brother. It would be less uncomfortable for him.”
Lan Xichen turned to him, not even able to hide his horror at the suggestion. “Absolutely not,” he said, momentarily forgetting to even pretend to be polite. “I…no. I cannot do that.”
Lan Qiren shook his head. “No, Xichen shouldn’t be punished for his brother’s actions. If we can’t outright tell them, then we…then we need to come up with another solution.”
“Perhaps ask them to move permanently to Lotus Pier?” someone suggested.
The fact that Lan Qiren was even considering letting his precious nephew go just proved how bad things really were.
The thing was, after getting married, Lan Wangji and Wei Wuxian had discovered the joys of sex. They had, of course, decided that they would engage in such activities on an everyday basis. And while they would have proceeded to do this in their own timeline had they not been transported to the past, the first few weeks of wedded bliss would have taken place outside of the Cloud Recesses, as the two travelled for a few months.
This time, however, stuck in the bodies of their younger selves, they had chosen to remain in the Cloud Recesses. And so the days and nights of passion and lust had begun, with Lan Wangji even more enraptured than ever at the sight of his beloved husband back in his own body. 
Wei Wuxian and Lan Wangji had no inhibitions when it came to sex. They were vigorous, wild, engulfed with desire, ridiculously kinky, and very, very loud. 
The Cloud Recesses, a quiet place to begin with, just wasn’t equipped to deal with this level of newly wedded bliss. 
Finally, after many sleepless nights, awkward meetings while they tried to come up with a solution (with no one feeling comfortable with simply walking over and telling them to quieten down a bit), and furiously cursing Wei Wuxian’s existence, they finally decided that the Jingshi was simply too close to everyone else’s quarters.
Lan Xichen approached his brother and brother-in-law, and informed them that he and his uncle had decided that Lan Wangji would now need a bigger home, what with him being married and all. A new, bigger house would be built for them as soon as possible.
Wei Wuxian beamed widely, happy that it seemed like people were actually accepting him this time around. Lan Wangji did not suspect that his beloved older brother had any ulterior motives, and agreed. Besides, a bigger house would be useful whenever he and Wei Wuxian decided to start a family (his mind momentarily moved to A-Yuan. ‘Someday soon,’ he thought to himself). 
And so, a new house was built for them, far, far away from where the other homes and disciple quarters were situated. Lan Wangji and Wei Wuxian moved, and things seemed to quiet down almost immediately. 
They had of course forgotten that the area where Lan Wangji and Wei Wuxian’s new home was built wasn’t quite as secluded as they’d initially thought. Someone else lived there too, far away from everyone else so that he could continue his seclusion uninterrupted.
…
Qinghheng-Jun woke up the first night after Wei Wuxian and Lan Wangji had moved into their new home to the sound of two lustful newly weds going at it. He lay silently in his bed, staring at the ceiling and wondering if he had finally lost his mind.
“Oh Er-gege,” an unfamiliar voice screamed, “oh, how cruel, your husband is such a fragile man — no, don’t stop, oh yes Hanguang-Jun, break me, tear me apart, destroy this wretched Yiling Patriarch utterly and completely — ”
Qingheng-Jun lay in bed, staring blankly in muted horror, unsure of what to do. When the screaming and banging finally stopped, it was well into the night, and his head felt like it was about to explode. 
He fell into an uneasy sleep, and woke up when it all started again a few hours later. 
Qingheng-Jun lasted a total of two days before it all just became a bit too much to bare. Perhaps he just hadn’t had human contact in a very long time, but he just couldn’t deal with it. He wasn’t a fool, he knew that those were the sounds of two people having sex. He just didn’t understand why he could hear them; he had chosen to spent his seclusion here for a reason. He was supposed to be far away from everyone else, so that he could spend his days in silence.
‘And HOW?!’ he thought, feeling despair rush though him. ‘How are they so loud? How do they do it that often, and for that long? And who TALKS that much during sex?!’ 
He wasn’t sure who he was hearing, but imagined that it might have been one of the sect elders. The younger disciples all lived in the disciple quarters. He briefly thought of his brother, but then quickly pushed the thought away, because it was too horrifying to even ponder.
He didn’t for a moment consider that it might be one of his sons, because to him, they were still just little boys.
Qingheng-Jun did not know about Lan Wangji’s marriage. It wasn’t that everyone had intentionally forgotten to tell him, it was just that…well, no one really saw Qingheng-Jun these days. He barely ever broke his seclusion, and hadn’t even seen his own sons in years. Lan Qiren had briefly thought about telling him, but amidst the stress of the whole situation, it had quickly slipped his mind.
And so, for a while at least, Qingheng-Jun had continued his seclusion uninterrupted, blissfully unaware that his youngest son was now a married man. That all ended later that night when, after an hour or so of listening to the sounds of two people passionately going at it, Qingheng-Jun’s self control shattered, and he found himself marching towards the neighbouring home in the middle of the night.
He knocked on the door loudly, his heart beating in his chest. It didn’t even matter that he was supposed to be in seclusion, and that he hadn’t spoken to anyone that wasn’t his brother in years. Right now all he wanted was to make it stop. 
For a moment there was silent, and then Qingheng-Jun heard the sound of footsteps approaching the doorway from inside. The door swung open a moment later, and he found himself face-to-face with an unfamiliar teenager. 
The sight took him off guard for a moment. He had expecting someone a lot older. “Ah,” he said, “would you — please keep it down?” 
He was trying to regain his bearings, and had just barely managed to do so when another person appeared beside the unfamiliar teen.
Qingheng-Jun froze, and, for a moment, wondered if he was dreaming. Why else would his youngest son be here? 
Qingheng-Jun turned and looked around, wondering if he was at the wrong house. And yet there was nothing else in the nearby vicinity, which meant that the horrors of the last few nights had happened here, which meant that — 
Qingheng-Jun stared forward blankly, unable to process any of it.
“Father?” Lan Wangji said, sounding shocked.
The other teenager let out a noise of surprise. “Father?” he repeated. “This is your dad, Lan Zhan?” 
“Father, would you like to come inside?” Lan Wangji sounded concerned. The other teenager was also watching him with wide eyes. They were in their bed clothes, their hair rumpled and out of place. The boy’s shoulders were littered with marks and bruises that Qingheng-Jun hadn’t seen on another person in a very long time.
Ignoring their curious and concerned calls, he walked numbly back to his own home, and climbed into bed.
The noises started again later that night.
…
The next morning, the news quickly spread around the Cloud Recesses that Qingheng-Jun had broken his seclusion. 
Qingheng-Jun didn’t even bother to be discrete, marching straight to his brothers rooms, and demanding to know what the hell was going on. Lan Qiren, suddenly remembering his brother, instantly paled. And if he felt maybe just the slightest big of vindictive pleasure, then he would never admit it out loud.
“What do you mean A-Zhan got married?!” Qingheng-Jun demanded, when Lan Qiren had explained the whole story to him. His voice was slightly hysteric. “He’s fifteen! He’s still a child!” 
“Do you think any of this makes sense?” Lan Qiren snapped. “I never would have imagined that Wangji would do something like this, and then — then — ” He shook his head in frustration.
Qingheng-Jun sighed, closing his eyes. “They’re like animals,” he muttered. “They never stop. I — is this how it’s like, nowadays? Is this what younger people do? Brother, I am honestly at a loss.” 
“I am honestly trying not to think about it too much,” Lan Qiren said. “Every time I do, I feel as if my mind is about to explode.” He had also felt like bursting into tears on numerous occasions, but he wasn’t going to tell his brother that.
A moment of silence passed, as the brothers sat quietly, lost in their thoughts. 
“I suppose nothing can be done about it now,” Qingheng-Jun sighed. “I have come to a decision. As of now, I will be ending my seclusion, and resuming my duties within the sect.”
Lan Qiren’s eyes widened in surprise. 
“I have been away far too long. It is about time I spent some time with my sons.” 
‘My children are out of control,’ he thought, but did not voice this thought out loud. 
Also, the thought of returning to his seclusion, and going back to that sounded like a nightmare. No, something had to change. 
“Very well then,” Lan Qiren said, nodding. “That is probably for the best.” 
“Yes,” Qingheng-Jun agreed. “And brother? I think it would be best if I moved somewhere a bit closer to where everyone else is.”
And far, far away from them went unsaid. 


Jin Zixuan Learns Something New 


In Jin Zixuan’s opinion, Wei Wuxian was an absolute lunatic. 
What kind of person ran off and got married to someone they had known for less than an hour? He was completely out of his mind, and it drove Jin Zixuan crazy to think that this idiot somehow still had more control over his own life than Jin Zixuan had over his. 
Wei Wuxian could marry a person he had known for less than an hour, and he could choose to do that. Jin Zixuan? He was stuck with Jiang Yanli, the girl his parents had chosen for him, and nothing would ever change that.
So maybe he had said a few things he shouldn’t have. He knew he wasn’t respecting Maiden Jiang, or the Jiang Sect, but he wasn’t in the mood to play nice. He wasn’t happy about this engagement, and he couldn’t understand why he should pretend to be.
Wei Wuxian had, unsurprisingly, punched him in the face. Jin Zixuan decided that he hated him even more. 
He had been fairly certain that Wei Wuxian would get kicked out after that whole mess. He already pushed it enough with all of his rule breaking, but there was no way Lan Qiren would tolerate physical violence as well. 
They now sat side-by-side in Lan Qiren’s office, as he berated the both of them (which Jin Zixuan found pretty unfair, since he wasn’t the one throwing punches around here).
“I have no choice but to expel you,” Lan Qiren snapped. “Pack your bags, and prepare to go home right now.” Was it just him, or did Lan Qiren sound way too happy when he said that?
“Okay,” Wei Wuxian agreed, all too easily. “So, do I go back to the Jingshi right now…?”
“What?”
“You told me to go home,” he said. “I live in the Jingshi. Lan Zhan and I are married, remember?”
Lan Qiren froze, and a dawning look of horror appeared on his face, as if he was only just remembering that there really was no getting rid of Wei Wuxian.
“I’ll go back to the Jingshi now, but first, there’s really something you should know, Uncle.” Lan Qiren winced. “You see, I was actually doing Jin Zixuan a favour.”

“What.” 

“Yes! Peacock — ” He turned to Jin Zixuan. “Your engagement to my sister will now be cancelled.” 
Jin Zixuan froze, his eyes widening. That…couldn’t be true, right?
“Yes, that’s exactly what you wanted, isn't it? Well now you’re free, and my Shijie is free of you. However, that isn’t what I mean when I call this a favour."
He continued to watch Jin Zixuan, who he simply sat there, unsure of how to respond.
"Now, free of any expectations, you can realise yourself what a kind, gentle, selfless person my sister really is. And then you will fall over yourself trying to win her back, and trying to get her to notice you. And she’ll accept you, even though she can do so much better, because that’s the kind of person she is. Loyal. Caring. Devoted.” He took a deep breath. “But that is for you to learn on your own.”
Jin Zixuan stared at him. Any angry retorts seemed to have left him, and he honestly didn’t know what to say to that.
Wei Wuxian stood up and walked out of the room.
“You — Wei Wuxian!” Lan Qiren spluttered. “Come back here now! We aren’t finished here.”
“What is wrong with him?” Jin Zixuan asked, more to himself than anything.
Lan Qiren simply grit his teeth in frustration.
…
Years later Jin Zixuan would realise that ‘Oh shit, Wei Wuxian was right, Jiang Yanli is amazing, I have realised the errors of my ways and please, please, please let her love me back and marry me,’ 
It was upon the arrival of this ground-breaking revelation, that Jin Zixuan would be cornered by Wei Wuxian, who turned out to be way more terrifying than he had ever imagined.
“Peacock,” Wei Wuxian said, as way of greeting, “if you even think of blurting out some half-hearted confession and running away because something like embarrassment stops you from giving my Shijie the best declaration of love ever, because that’s nothing less than what she deserves, you will regret it.”
Jin Zixuan stared. “I…how did you get into my room?”
“Never mind that. Here.” Wei Wuxian passed him a sheet of paper. Jin Zixuan stared down at it blankly. “That is a list of all of my Shijie’s favourite things, places, hobbies — read it, learn it, and make sure that when you do tell her how you feel, you make her feel like the most special woman in the world, which she is. I want courting gifts, day trips, poetry, music, the most romantic words since mine and Lan Zhan’s confession — ”
Jin Zixuan winced at the memory. 
“ — and Shijie will get everything she deserves, is that understood?” 
Jin Zixuan nodded numbly, and thought to himself, ‘Didn’t Lan Wangji meet you on a rooftop, have pre-marital sex with you, and then elope with you without telling anyone?’ 
He, of course, was not aware of the years of excruciating pining, misunderstandings, life-and-death situations, literal death, sieges, whippings, resurrections, and more misunderstandings that had made up the years of unknowing courtship that Lan Wangji and Wei Wuxian had underwent.
“Uh, Wei Wuxian,” he said. “How exactly did you know I would change my mind about Maiden Jiang?”
Wei Wuxian snorted. “Are you kidding me? This is my Shijie we’re talking about. You would be even more of an idiot than I thought if you didn’t eventually realise how amazing she really is.”
Well, Jin Zixuan wasn’t going to argue with that.
…
After around a month of courtship, involving numerous gifts, visits to the prettiest locations he could think of, the freshest food he could get his hands on, poetry he spent many sleepless nights trying to squeeze out of a brain that had always thought poetry was rather ridiculous, an original song that he had paid someone to compose since he didn’t have a musical bone in his body, and yet had spent every second of the time it was being created telling the composer exactly what he wanted, and exactly how it was supposed to capture the way Jiang Yanli made him feel, and think, and love, until the man had all but begged him to leave the room because he couldn’t think — and all because Wei Wuxian hadn’t been able to shut up about how romantic original songs were, and how Lan Wangji had written one just for him and named it Wangxian of all fucking things — 
Well. At long last, Jiang Yanli had accepted his feelings (and reassured him multiple times that a simple confession would have sufficed) and he was now engaged to the most wonderful woman in the entire world.
He did end up telling her all about his confrontation with her brother, because Jiang Yanli deserved nothing more than absolute honesty from her future husband, and also because he wanted Wei Wuxian to suffer just a bit.
Jiang Yanli giggled after hearing the whole story. “Yes, A-Xian can be very protective,” she said simply. “He didn’t tell you not to propose, did he? I think that means he approves.”
Jin Zixuan blinked in surprise. Oh, he hadn’t thought of it that way.
Jiang Yanli smiled, and decided not to say that while yes, her A-Xian was undoubtedly motivated by protection and love, it was probably a bit of payback as well. After all, upon hearing about his elopement with Lan Wangji, Jiang Yanli had demanded to know every single detail of their courtship and marriage from him — a task that had taken hours. 
She had, of course, only the best intentions in doing this. She had even given him plenty of food as they’d spoken, some of Wei Wuxian’s favourite dishes. And perhaps no one but Wei Wuxian could actually eat those dishes since they were basically death traps, but perhaps that had simply slipped her mind.
To his credit, Lan Wangji had finished every one of the bowls that Jiang Yanli had forced upon him.
...


The Death of Wen Ruohan


While away on their honeymoon, Wei Wuxian and Lan Wangji had made sure that the entire week wasn’t just filled with fun and games. Oh, they had undoubtedly had their fun (the disgruntled inn employees had been a testament to that), but they were fully aware that they had work to do as well. 
And work they had. They’d made a quick trip to Qishan, and had gotten themselves quickly acquainted with the branch family of the Wen Sect. The sight of the little family he had built for himself during his time in the Burial Mounds had made Wei Wuxian’s heart clench, and he had burst into tears the moment he had managed to get away for a bit, crying for everything he had lost in the comforting embrace of his husband.
They had spent the next few days sightseeing around the Qishan area, and trying to convince Wen Qing that they weren’t insane, and that they really were time travellers. Wen Qing had influence amongst her part of the family, and she was smart, and resourceful. And, importantly, she was one of the few branch family members that Wen Ruohan actually held in high regard.
They had managed to convince her, eventually. And after telling her enough about the horrors of the future that she was just as invested in changing events (although she had looked like she wanted to kill them where they stood when Wei Wuxian had mentioned Wen Ning’s death), Wei Wuxian was pleased enough with their progress.
The rest of the year had involved the back and forth exchange of letters, and the occasional visit whenever they got the chance (and since Wei Wuxian and Lan Wangji really didn’t care about what anyone else thought, this was quite frequently), and soon the time came for them to enact their grand plan.
“You’re sure this is going to work?” Wen Qing asked, her eyes narrowed slightly.
“Wen Qing! Have some faith! This will definitely work,” Wei Wuxian said, his cheeks puffed out as he tried to swallow a mouthful of rice while talking at the same time. 
They were sat around a table in Granny’s home, cheerfully having lunch, not even worrying about the fact that in a few hours, they would be killing off Wen Ruohan, Wen Chao, and anyone else in the main branch of the Wen Sect. They had been the main threats during the Wen’s bloody reign, the main source of support for Wen Ruohan.
After multiple visits over the course of the year, Wei Wuxian and Lan Wangji had quickly endeared themselves to the group that would have one day become the Wen Remnants. 
Wen Qing huffed, and turned to Lan Wangji. “What do you think?” she asked him. “Do we have a chance of pulling this off?” 
“Mn,” Lan Wangji said, and Wen Qing instantly relaxed. Wei Wuxian pouted; honestly, no one had any faith in his word.
“Not much to pull off,” Uncle Four said, snorting. “Just those two going in and killing everyone — and honestly, I don’t understand how you’re going to do it. This is Wen Ruohan we’re talking about.” He shrugged. “You’re funeral, though.”
Granny gave him a whack on the head, scowling.
Wen Ning shifted uncomfortably in his seat, his gaze lowered. “Oh, be careful,” he said. 
“No really, we have this under control,” Wei Wuxian said, smiling reassuringly. “Wen Qing informed us when the next meeting amongst the main clan would be — thanks for that by the way — and ensured that they would all be there. Lan Zhan and I definitely have this under control, okay? Trust me, we have a secret weapon that none of them will be expecting.” Demonic cultivation that no one knew about could be an excellent bonus. “And then when all of that is over, that’s when you come in.”
He gave them a wide, beaming smile. The others smiled back, a tad bit uncertainly. Wen Ning looked like he was sweating bullets, and Wen Qing let out a huff and prayed to the Gods that this would actually work out.
…
A few hours later, Wei Wuxian and Lan Wangji returned. The Wen remnants immediately sat up, pretending that they hadn’t been silently panicking the whole time. Wen Ning had no such qualms, hurrying over to them, his eyes wide.
“You’re okay!” he cried, eyes wide in relief. “Young Masters — are you alright? Are you — ?”
“Wen Ning, we’re fine,” Wei Wuxian said, laughing.
“Mn,” Lan Wangji agreed. “They are all dead.” 
Everyone stared at him blankly. Oh, they had been reassured numerous times that everything would be fine, but they hadn’t fully believed it until now. Lan Wangji didn’t seem at all bothered by what he had said; he didn’t like killing, and the Gusu Lan Sect disapproved of it, but he had taken his fair share of lives during the war.
And to protect Wei Wuxian, and the people he cared about…well, there was very little he wouldn’t do.
“You…actually did it,” Wen Qing said, sounding slightly stunned. 
“Yes!”
“How though? Honestly — this is Wen Ruohan we’re talking about! You don’t just — walk in and kill him!” 
“No,” Wei Wuxian agreed. “But we have the great Hanguang-Jun on our side — ”
“Who?” Wen Ning asked, frowning slightly. 
“…Ahh, never mind about that. I keep forgetting certain things haven’t happened yet…anyway, we also had something that Wen Ruohan absolutely did not see coming. So, we took him out with my demonic cultivation first; he was surprised because he hadn’t seen anything like it, and he underestimated us, and that made it easy. And then when the main threat was out of the way, my corpses mostly took care of the rest. Lan Zhan finished off whoever was left.:
Silence.
“…I’m going to get the alcohol out,” Uncle Four announced.
…
“Sect Leader Wen is dead,” Lan Qiren told them when they returned to the Cloud Recesses a day later. 
“Oh, how tragic,” Wei Wuxian said. “Should I send some flowers? Or some fruit? Lan Zhan, what do you think?”
“Flowers and fruit,” Lan Wangji said, after a brief moment of consideration.
Lan Qiren ground his teeth together, and wished for the days when his nephew was still perfect, and the world still made sense.
…
“So…tell me again, what exactly happened?” 
The remaining sect leaders sat together in an impromptu meeting. Qingheng-Jun, having long since left his seclusion behind, was in attendance along with Lan Qiren.
“Sect Leader Wen is dead, along with the entirety of the main branch of the Wen family,” Lan Qiren said. “As for how they died…well…” He took a deep breath. “It appears that they were planning to attack and set fire to the Cloud Recesses. They engaged in a…practice run-through of what would happen and…and…”
Everyone stared at him expectantly, as if they hadn’t already heard the whole story many times before.
“…It appears that they…accidentally set themselves on fire…”
The room descended into silence as its occupants tried to process that.
In all actuality, Wen Qing and Wen Ning had set fire to the building to hide all evidence of the dead bodies. Wen Ning had then created a fake written document, with information about a planned siege on the Cloud Recesses, with plans to burn it down, and another document detailing the supposed contents of the meeting — a complete practice run-through of what would be happening once the attack would take place.
Of course, none of this had actually happened, but it wasn’t like anyone else would know about it. Wei Wuxian had suggested the whole thing, finding it hilarious for reasons that the Wens still weren’t sure about.
“They accidentally set themselves on fire?” Jiang Fengmian repeated.
“Yes.”
“…Wen Ruohan accidentally set himself on fire?” 
Lan Qiren sighed. “Yes.” And then, as an afterthought, “And both his sons, and every member of the main Wen family.”
It sounded ridiculous even saying it out loud.
“Does it really matter that much?” Nie Mingjue asked. He had been in an excellent mood ever since learning that Wen Ruohan had died. The thought of him dying such a humiliating death even made up for the fact that it hadn’t been Nie Mingjue himself who had killed him. “He’s dead, and that’s what matters.”
“We shouldn’t sound so pleased about this,” Jiang Fengmian said, in a tone that should have been admonishing. In all honesty, he really didn’t care that much. This was all a huge relief. 
“As if you all aren’t just as happy about this,” Nie Mingjue said, rolling his eyes. “And look at this! He was planning on attacking the Cloud Recesses. He got what he deserved, in my opinion.” 
Lan Qiren and Qingheng-Jun exchanged wary glances, all too aware of Lan Wangji and Wei Wuxian’s suspicious departure and return during the time of the deaths.
“Apparently that doctor — Wen Qing — is now the leader of the Wen Sect,” Nie Mingjue said. He didn’t seem particularly bothered, though Lan Qiren had definitely taken a moment to process the idea of a women leading the Wen Sect when he had first heard the news. 
“Yes,” Jiang Fengmian agreed. “The entire main branch of the Wen family perished in the fire — ”
Nie Mingjue let out a snort of laughter.
“ — and only the branch family members are left. Wen Qing’s brother apparently had no desire to take on the role, so she is now in charge.” 
There was a moment of silence as they all tried to process the idea of Wen Ruohan dying in an accidental fire.
(“What exactly did A-Zhan and A-Xian do?” Qingheng-Jun would later ask his brother, with an exhausted look on his face, as the two tried to contemplate what the hell their lives had become.
“It’s better we don’t know,” Lan Qiren would say, because it was better than saying, “I have no bloody idea,” or “This is your fault for marrying that damned woman. This is ALL her influence!”).
Nie Mingjue swung back a jar of wine, grinning widely.

Meet Our New Child! 


Lan Xichen had always prided himself on being one of the few people able to truly understand his brother. No matter what situation, he could always know what his brother was thinking or feeling.
Ever since Wei Wuxian had entered their lives, that talent seemed to have vanished. Nowadays, Lan Xichen didn’t seem to know what his brother was thinking. Lan Wangji had gone from being a quiet, shy, repressed teenager to a married man, literally overnight. Lan Xichen had not seen that coming. Years later, he still couldn’t figure out how he could ever have seen that coming. 
Oh, he definitely liked Wei Wuxian, and had soon come to see him as another little brother. That didn’t mean he didn’t wish his life made just a bit more sense these days.
Time passed, and Lan Xichen settled into a state of acceptance. His brother was strange, his brother-in-law was strange, but they were both happy, and they clearly loved each other, and Lan Xichen could work with that. Besides, he could handle their odd quirks. 
Oh so he thought, until they returned from their latest random disappearance. His brother was carrying a child, and neither he nor Wei Wuxian seemed surprised that he was there. Lan Xichen felt mounting dread build up inside him. 
“Xichen-ge!” Wei Wuxian called out, waving cheerfully. “Xichen-ge, guess what? We’re parents now!”
Lan Xichen stared.
“Brother,” Lan Wangji said calmly, as if anything in this situation made any sense. “This is A-Yuan. He is Wei Ying and my son.”
Silence.
“He is your nephew.”
“Yes,” Lan Xichen said weakly. “That…my nephew. Yes.”
The child beamed up at him.
“I — I’m sorry, where did this child come from?” His brother and Wei Wuxian had told them that they had a quick trip to make, and had then disappeared for two weeks. It was hardly alarming these days, and Lan Xichen hadn’t thought twice about it.
Showing up again with a child was definitely not what he was expecting. Although, Lan Xichen supposed, it wasn’t as strange as running off to marry someone you had only just met. And definitely not as strange as Lan Wangji running off to marry someone he had only just met.
It was still pretty strange though, and Lan Xichen was still trying to wrap his head around all of it.
His baby brother was a father now. 
Yes, these days, his life made very little sense.
…
“I’m sorry, but who said you could be a parent?” Jiang Cheng demanded.
“No one,” Wei Wuxian said, poking A-Yuan’s cheek. The toddler beamed up at him. “Lan Zhan and I make great parents though!”
“Granny,” Lan Wangji reminded him.
“Oh right…Granny said we could be parents. This little one’s mother passed away a few months ago, and his father was never really in the picture…Granny was having a hard time taking care of him, what with her age and everything, and Lan Zhan and I just kind of bonded with him…”
(Plus, it was A-Yuan, there was no way they wouldn’t love him upon first glance).
“I don’t get why you spend so much time with those Wens,” Jiang Cheng said, shaking his head. He eyed the child, and then shook his head again. “God, that poor kid, having you for a dad.”
Wei Wuxian scowled. “Hey! I happen to make a great dad! Right, Lan Zhan?” 
“Mn,” Lan Wangji said. “Wei Ying is a good father.”
Wei Wuxian beamed. 
Jiang Cheng snorted. “Yeah sure, let’s just pretend as if he doesn’t agree with everything you say.” 
Jiang Yanli watched A-Yuan with a smile on her face. The Jiang siblings, Lan Wangji, and the newest addition to the family were sat in the Jingshi, sipping on tea. 
“He’s adorable, A-Xian,” Jiang Yanli said, and nearly squealed in delight when A-Yuan smiled at her. Oh, she was definitely ready to have children of her own.
(If she said this aloud to either of her brothers, they would probably lose their minds, and then head off to kill Jin Zixuan). 
“Welcome to the family, A-Yuan,” she said. 
“Lan Yuan,” Wei Wuxian said, lifting the little toddler higher, and beaming at him. “I’ve missed you, little one.”
Lan Wangji let out a hum of agreement, and moved to stand closer to his husband and son. Jiang Yanli and Jiang Cheng exchanged bewildered expressions, but didn’t bother to voice how their brother could possibly miss a child he had just adopted. By now, they were used to Wei Wuxian’s strange behaviour.
Meanwhile, Lan Wangji and Wei Wuxian watched their new son, a feeling of calm settling over them. Finally, their family was complete again. This time A-Yuan would grow up knowing the love of both of his parents, and his entire extended family. He would see his grandmother regularly, and all of his aunts, and uncles, and cousins. He would know exactly who he was, and would never feel ashamed of his family, or of his past. He would never know hurt, or pain, or hunger.
They would protect him this time around; they would keep him safe, and loved, and happy. 
A-Yuan beamed up at the two people who already loved him more than the world, the final piece to their little family. 
…
“No.”
“Yes.”

“No.”

“Yes!” Qinheng-Jun beamed widely, and took a large gulp of tea. “Brother, I’m a grandfather!”
“Oh God!” Lan Qiren cried, and Qingheng-Jun mistook this for joy. He nodded happily. 
“Yes! A-Zhan and A-Xian have adopted a little boy. His name is A-Yuan, and oh, he is simply adorable — ”
“Where did they get a child from?! Who thought it would be a good idea to let Wei Wuxian raise a child?!” Lan Qiren’s voice was filled with despair, as his mind was suddenly filled with images of a young child dressed in the robes of the Lan Sect, advancing on him with a manic grin on his face as he prepared to shave off Lan Qiren’s goatee. 
No child raised by Wei Wuxian would ever be the epitome of serenity and virtue, the very values of the Lan Sect that all its disciples should embody. Wei Wuxian would undoubtedly taint the poor child, and oh God, Lan Qiren would be forced to put up with him because he would be family. 
“Is it too late to send them to Lotus Pier?” he asked shakily. 
“Hmm?” Qingheng-Jun glanced up from where he had been staring off into space, imagining an adorable toddler dressed in the Lan Sect white. Ever since ending his seclusion, and realising that his family had gone completely out of control while he was gone, Qingheng-Jun had thrown himself into a life of trying to be a family man. This was much to the frustration of Lan Qiren, who was all for his brother’s change in attitude, until he realised that Qingheng-Jun utterly adored Wei Wuxian.
“Wei Wuxian and Wangji,” Lan Qiren said. “Is it too late to ship them off to Lotus Pier?” Yu Ziyuan might try to kill him, or at the very least cause him bodily harm, but he could deal with her. He wasn’t sure how much longer he could deal with Wei Wuxian.
Qingheng-Jun’s brow furrowed. “Why on earth would we do that? Now Brother, I want to buy a gift for my new grandson — what do you think — ?” 
“Oh my god.” Lan Qiren’s face paled when a thought suddenly occurred to him. “If — if Xichen doesn’t marry off and have children of his own, then will Wei Wuxian’s child be the next Sect Leader after him?” 
“Yes, most likely,” Qingheng-Jun said. “Now, about that gift — “
Lan Qiren stood up abruptly. “I need to — I need to go and speak to the matchmakers,” he said, hurrying to the doorway. “We need to marry Xichen off as soon as possible, and ensure the sanctity and values of this sect! A child raised by Wei Wuxian would utterly destroy everything that we stand for!” 
Lan Qiren then dashed straight out of the room, either to hunt down a matchmaker, or find Lan Xichen and inform him that he would soon be getting married. 
Qingheng-Jun hummed and sipped his tea, deciding that he would go and visit his new grandson again as soon as possible. 

 The Heir of Gusu Lan (otherwise known as, “Lan Qiren Makes a Big Mistake”) 

Lan Qiren spent the next year diligently trying to convince Lan Xichen to marry. He resorted to any methods possible — he contacted matchmakers, tried to subtly arrange outings between his nephew and any eligible woman he could find, tried to organise formal betrothals. Nothing seemed to work. It didn’t help that everyone else in his family were too busy cooing over the hellspawn that was Wei Wuxian’s child to try and help him in his crucial mission.
How could Xichen possibly be this opposed to marriage?! Just look at who he was related to!
Now if Lan Qiren had maybe paid a bit more attention to his new grand-nephew, instead of obsessing over the future of the sect, he might have realised that the boy was absolutely perfect. Right now, his stress levels were through the roof, and getting to know a toddler was the last thing on his mind.
Perhaps if he had, all of this could have been avoided. Instead, Lan Qiren persisted, deciding that if Lan Xichen refused to marry, then other measures would have to be taken.
…
It was perfectly fine if Lan Xichen decided not to marry, Lan Qiren thought. In fact, it was more than fine. Who needed any more spouses around here? Surely no one could be worse than Wei Wuxian, but did he really want to risk it?
No, he had come up with the perfect solution to make everyone happy. Lan Xichen could remain happily single for as long as he wanted, and Lan Qiren could sleep peacefully knowing that the future of their sect wasn’t in the hands of Wei Wuxian’s child.
The orphan boy he was dragging behind him would be happy too. He was getting a new family, a rise in rank — what was there to complain about?
His solution was perfect; Lan Xichen could remain single if he wanted. After all, you didn’t need to be married to have a child. There were plenty of orphans around, though of course, the child would have to be of Lan blood. Lan Qiren wasn’t risking anything else. This child would be respectful, and virtuous, and disciplined, and everything he had once thought Wangji to be until his worst nightmare had come true.
The small child, walking quietly and solemnly beside, him was perfect. A distant relative of the Lans, whose parents had recently died on a night hunt. Here was a child who was in need of comfort, and a family, and of course Lan Qiren would provide that for him.
And if this child ensured that the Cloud Recesses wouldn’t one day be ruled by a duplicate of Wei Wuxian, then he wasn’t truly doing this for selfish reasons. This was for the good of the sect. 
He knocked on Lan Xichen’s door. It opened a moment later, and his nephew stood in the doorway.
“Uncle,” Lan Xichen greeted.
“Xichen,” Lan Qiren said, and thrust the little boy towards him.
Lan Xichen stared. “Hello?” he said uncertainly. “Uncle, who is this?” 
It took Lan Qiren a moment to remember the child’s name. “This is Lan Jingyi,” he said. “Your new son.”

“What?” 

“He has no parents,” Lan Qiren said. “You have no child. It is a perfect match.” He glanced down at Jingyi, who blinked up at him, looking quiet, and serious, and oh so perfect. “Always be obedient and virtuous, Jingyi. Don’t let outside influences sway you.”
The child blinked up at him in response. 
“Uncle!” Lan Xichen cried, with more than a little desperation in his voice. 
Lan Qiren turned around and strode away. He had done his job. Xichen would acclimatise soon enough; if Wei Wuxian could figure out how to raise a child, surely Xichen could do the same.
…
What Lan Qiren failed to understand was that his initial assessment of Lan Jingyi was completely wrong. When he had first met Jingyi, the child had been consumed by grief by the recent loss of his parents. It had made him quiet and withdrawn, but this was hardly his usual temperament.
Jingyi, on a normal day, was loud, exuberant, talkative and loud. He was everything that Lan Qiren despised. Lan Qiren, unfortunately, would soon come to realise this.
Lan Xichen remained in a state of shock for some time after the adoption. He still couldn’t seem to understand what had happened. Very little seemed to make sense these days.
For some reason, Wei Wuxian seemed to find the whole thing hilarious. He had cooed over Jingyi, cuddling him close while he beamed from ear to ear, his eyes shining with mirth. Even Lan Wangji had barely been able to hide his amusement, something Lan Xichen had seen clearly from the slight twitch of his lips, and the furrow of his brow.
A-Yuan had adored his new cousin from the moment he had met him. Qingheng-Jun had just been excited to have another grandson to spoil. The man had well and truly become a family man these days, and every time Lan Xichen caught sight of his father playing with his new grandsons in the rabbit fields, he’d wonder if he had walked into some parallel universe.
He voiced these thoughts out loud once, and Wei Wuxian had burst out laughing yet again. Sometimes, Lan Xichen just couldn’t understand his brother-in-law.
The thing was, Lan Xichen wasn’t ready to be a father. He hadn’t even considered it, and here he was, in charge of a child, and not completely sure what he was doing.
“I wouldn’t worry too much,” Wei Wuxian said, grinning as they watched A-Yuan and Jingyi playing. “Something tells me that kid is going to grow up just fine.”
…
Lan Xichen ended up utterly and completely adoring his son. 
He doted on him, and indulged him in pretty much everything. If anyone brought it up, he would just brush it off, and tell himself that his brother and Wei Wuxian were much worse with their own child.
Qingheng-Jun continued to fight for the title of grandfather of the year, something that Jiang Fengmian would happily battle him for. 
The children grew, and with them, their personalities blossomed. A-Yuan — now Sizhui — was calm, focused, and gentle, the very embodiment of a perfect Lan disciple. Oh, he had his devious side as well — how could he not, with Wei Wuxian for a parent — but he hid that well enough.
Basically, he was everything that Lan Qiren wanted in a disciple.
And Jingyi? If Lan Sizhui was the embodiment of the Lan Sect values, Lan Jingyi was the embodiment of everything that made up Wei Wuxian. He basically was Wei Wuxian in miniature Lan form.
Lan Qiren felt like he was living through a very long, very vivid nightmare, and he kept expecting to wake up and for all of this to go away. Xichen would still be childless, Lan Wangji and Wei Wuxian would still be wreaking havoc, his brother would still be useless, and Sizhui — sweet, precious, perfect A-Yuan, who he had misunderstood so, so much — would still be the next sect heir after Lan Xichen.
A nightmare. This had to be a nightmare. Lan Qiren couldn’t have caused this — this travesty. If he had — if this was real — then that meant that this — this — deviant; this child that was the very epitome of what a Lan was not supposed to be, would one day be in charge of this sect.
This child, who spoke too loudly, who sounded like he was trying to burst eardrums when he laughed, who argued and spoke back to his elders, who pranked people, and who couldn’t stay still if you glued him to his chair — this child would be the future leader of the Gusu Lan Sect.
Oh please, please let Lan Qiren be dead when that time came.
‘No,’ he thought a moment later. No, that would hardly be fair. He may be lying peacefully in his grave by that point, but could he really abandon his sect? He may not have to bear the brunt of his nightmare, but the future of his beloved sect was depending on him right now. Who else would do something about this? Not his brother, who was too busy chasing after his grandsons with hearts in his eyes, or Lan Xichen, who acted like his son was some perfect, innocent little thing, and not a devious little monster.
Not Wangji, who he had long since given up on. 
Oh god, oh god, what could he do? There was nothing he could do. Lan Jingyi was now officially Lan Xichen’s son, and there was no way that would ever change, and Xichen would (very politely of course) toss him off the edge of the Cloud Recesses if he even suggested it. 
“Brother,” he said the next time he saw Qingheng-Jun, with some desperation in his voice. Qingheng-Jun may have too busy doting on his grandchildren and trying to make up for lost time with his sons to actually remember that he was still the Sect Leader, but he was still technically in charge. Maybe, just maybe, he would listen to reason.
“Brother, something must be done. We…we need to change the line of succession, immediately. Sizhui must be the next heir after Xichen.”
Qingheng-Jun, who was thinking about the trip he would be making to Caiyi Town with Jingyi and Sizhui later that day, absentmindedly hummed.
“Yes?” Lan Qiren asked eagerly. “You agree?”
“Yes, I think Jingyi will make a wonderful Sect Leader one day,” he said absentmindedly. “Qiren, do you think I should take them to that little restaurant near the edge of town, or would the one near — ”
Lan Qiren whirled around and stormed away, feeling despair consume him.
He had done this. They could have had Sizhui as the future heir and hope of their sect, but he had been blinded by his anger at Wei Wuxian. Yes, Wei Wuxian was unruly, and wild, and uncontrollable, and he despised the man with every fibre of his being, but he had forgotten one very important fact — Sizhui was also Lan Wangji’s son. And yes, Wangji may be corrupted by Wei Wuxian, but surely there was enough of his righteous nephew under the deviant, shameless menace that Wei Wuxian had turned him into, and surely that would be enough to lead Sizhui down the right path.
If only he had thought this through. If only he had waited. 
Now, he had singlehandedly brought about the downfall of his sect. Someday, they would live in a world where Lan Jingyi was the leader of Gusu Lan.
